Award.AwardTitle: DMREF: Integrated Computational Framework for Designing Dynamically Controlled Alloy-Oxide Heterostructures
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical Description: Many technologies rely on heterostructures made of materials with very different chemistries. Examples include (i) turbine blades in jet engines, (ii) microelectronic applications that rely on semiconductor-oxide heterostructures and (iii) electrochemical energy storage devices such as all solid-state batteries. Heterostructures are often out of equilibrium due to the close proximity of very different chemistries. This results in the evolution of the heterostructure with a concomitant degradation of its functional capabilities over time. Predicting the evolution of heterostructures consisting of widely differing chemistries remains one of the biggest challenges in materials science and requires a description of processes that span widely varying length and time scales. The processes that dominate heterostructure evolution are common to most other non-equilibrium processes in the solid state. This project will lead to the development of an openly distributable framework that rigorously integrates theory, experiment and computation to predict and elucidate the evolution of complex materials heterostructures. It will address an important challenge within the Materials Genome Initiative of linking the electronic structure of the constituent chemistries of a complex materials system to its behavior at technologically relevant length and time scales.

Technical Description: The aim of this project is to develop a rigorous framework and accompanying predictive infrastructure that integrates multi-scale computation with precise experimental characterization to predict and elucidate the evolution of complex heterostructures and multi-phase coexistence. A specific focus will target the measurement and prediction of thermodynamic and kinetic properties of individual and combined oxidation processes in selected model alloys. The methods to be developed and integrated will be more generally applicable to evolving multi-phase coexistence between metallic, semiconducting and insulating phases, where evolution requires atomic diffusion, electron transport, phase nucleation and growth coupled with interface migration. The activity will focus on model systems presenting a clear case for benchmarking and validating multiscale models that bridge descriptions of atomistic processes with continuum length scales. A major objective is to define design criteria for the stability and evolution of oxide/metal structures. Experimental measurements will be tightly integrated with modeling tasks, providing both input and validation. While the emphasis is on oxidation in model systems that exhibit a range of dynamic phenomena involving interfaces between different phases, the tools and integrated research methodology will be applicable to any dynamically evolving heterostructure system coupling phase evolution with atomic and electronic transport. This includes batteries, fuel cells, and corrosion processes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Oxides, which consist of a metal and oxygen usually in a crystalline form, are of tremendous importance to many technological applications. Oxides serve as coatings on structural alloys to protect them against extreme environments, as well as constituents of ceramic matrix composites. They also exhibit a wide variety of electronic, magnetic and electrochemical properties that make them invaluable building blocks in many device applications. The objective of this DMREF project has been to develop an infrastructure that integrates synthesis, multi-scale computation and precise experimental characterization to predict and elucidate the generation of oxide heterostructures through the reaction of metals with their environment. The DMREF team combined the requisite skills in theory, computation, synthesis and characterization.

The oxidation of metallic alloys is a complex process that remains poorly understood and very challenging to model rigorously. A mechanistic understanding of oxidation processes along with a computational infrastructure to predict oxidation is essential to enable the rational design of alloys and synthesis approaches that yield desired oxide phases and oxide microstructures. As a model system, the DMREF project focused on the oxidation of Ti and its alloys, which are of great importance in a wide variety of technological applications. Ti alloys are used in aerospace applications due to their high specific strength and corrosion resistance and as biomedical implants due to their excellent biocompatibility. The oxides of Ti also exhibit exceptional photocatalytic activity and have potential to serve as electrode materials in Li-ion and Na-ion batteries. In all these applications, the oxides of Ti play an important role and precise control of oxide formation during synthesis is crucial. The oxidation of a metal such as Ti also poses significant additional challenges when compared to most other metals and alloys due to the existence of a very large number of stable and metastable oxides and suboxides and especially to the ability of Ti to simultaneously dissolve oxygen to very high concentrations. The unusually high oxygen solubility in Ti makes it especially challenging to form a stable protective oxide scale on Ti alloys as it is continuously undermined from below due to oxygen dissolution.

New computational tools and methodologies were developed in the course of this project to enable the multi-scale prediction of non-equilibrium materials processes such oxidation. Furthermore, the experimental and computational focus on the oxidation of Ti and several of its alloys led to a deeper understanding of the interplay between thermodynamic driving forces and kinetic processes during oxidation. New insights were developed about oxidation on substrates that are capable of dissolving high concentrations of oxygen, where constant oxygen dissolution destabilizes oxide scales. These insights will provide invaluable guidance to future efforts to design protective oxide scales on Ti and its alloys.

Specific project outcomes include:

-       The development of new computational tools and methodologies that link atomistic simulations with continuum approaches to predict the non-equilibrium evolution of materials as it occurs during oxidation processes.

-       The leveraging of machine learning tools in computational materials research, both for atomistic level simulations and for continuum optimization studies.

-       The generation of a fundamental understanding of the interactions between Ti and interstitial elements such as oxygen, nitrogen and carbon and a refined characterization of phase stability within the Ti-O, Ti-C and Ti-N binary systems.

-       The development of experimental approaches to investigate the interplay between oxide formation and oxygen dissolution in the alloy.

-       The discovery of the beneficial role of Si in controlling oxidation of Ti and the generation of a mechanistic understanding of the role that Si plays in fostering a dense protective oxide scale.

-       The training of graduate students in a new paradigm of materials research that involves an iterative feedback loop between modeling, characterization and synthesis

-       The results of experimental, methodological and computational efforts, which were disseminated over thirteen archival peer reviewed publications.

-       The project supported contributions to two open source software packages (CASM and mechanoChemIGA) that aim to predict thermodynamic and kinetic properties of materials starting from first principles.

The project has had broader impacts on education, science, and technology by: 1) providing an open framework rigorously integrating theory, experiment and computation to enable the design of solids with controlled oxidation behavior; 2) enabling the design of higher-performance alloys required for the development of higher-efficiency power generation, in the fossil-fired, nuclear and fuel cell sectors; 3) exposing students and professionals to cutting-edge characterization tools preparing them for future careers in the field of Integrated Computational Materials Engineering (ICME); 4) impacting other fields where oxidation and corrosion are significant issues (e.g. battery materials, electrochemistry); and 5) promoting participation of students and professionals from under-represented minorities in an open learning setting that mixes fundamental and applied work.
